1.brief: a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
properly, chastisement; figuratively, reproof, warning or instruction; also restraint
father, in a literal and immediate, or figurative and remote application
properly, to make mouths at, i.e. to scoff; hence (from the effort to pronounce a foreign language) to interpret, or (generally) intercede
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to hear intelligently (often with implication of attention, obedience, etc.; causatively, to tell, etc.)

2.brief: the mouth (as the means of blowing), whether literal or figurative (particularly speech); specifically edge, portion or side; adverbially (with preposition) according to
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)

good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
to cover (with a garment); figuratively, to act covertly; by implication, to pillage
violence; by implication, wrong; by meton. unjust gain

3.brief: to guard, in a good sense (to protect, maintain, obey, etc.) or a bad one (to conceal, etc.)
the mouth (as the means of blowing), whether literal or figurative (particularly speech); specifically edge, portion or side; adverbially (with preposition) according to
properly, to hedge about (as with thorns), i.e. guard; generally, to protect, attend to, etc.
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
to dispart (the feet or lips), i.e. become licentious
the lip (as a natural boundary); by implication, language; by analogy, a margin (of a vessel, water, cloth, etc.)
properly, a dissolution; concretely, a ruin, or (abstractly) consternation

4.brief: a non-entity; generally used as a negative particle
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
properly, incised or (active) incisive; hence (as noun masculine or feminine) a trench (as dug), gold (as mined), a threshing-sledge (having sharp teeth); (figuratively) determination; also eager
to be fat; transitively, to fatten (or regard as fat); specifically to anoint; figuratively, to satisfy;  to remove (fat) ashes (of sacrifices)

5.brief: a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause
an untruth; by implication, a sham (often adverbial)
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
to smell bad; figuratively, to be offensive morally
to blush; figuratively, to be ashamed, disappointed; causatively, to shame, reproach

6.brief: rightness (abstractly), subjectively (rectitude), objectively (justice), morally (virtue) or figuratively (prosperity)
to guard, in a good sense (to protect, maintain, obey, etc.) or a bad one (to conceal, etc.)
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
properly, to wrench, i.e. (figuratively) to subvert
an offence (sometimes habitual sinfulness), and its penalty, occasion, sacrifice, or expiation; also (concretely) an offender

7.brief: there is or are (or any other form of the verb to be, as may suit the connection)
properly, to accumulate; chiefly (specifically) to grow (causatively, make) rich
a non-entity; generally used as a negative particle
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)

8.brief: properly, a cover, i.e. (literally) a village (as covered in); (specifically) bitumen (as used for coating), and the henna plant (as used for dyeing); figuratively, a redemption-price
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to hear intelligently (often with implication of attention, obedience, etc.; causatively, to tell, etc.)

9.brief: illumination or (concrete) luminary (in every sense, including lightning, happiness, etc.)
probably to brighten up, i.e. (figuratively) be (causatively, make) blithe or gleesome
a lamp (i.e. the burner) or light (literally or figuratively)
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
to be extinguished; figuratively, to expire or be dried up

10.brief: properly, leanness, i.e. (figuratively) limitation; only adverbial, merely, or conjunctional, although
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
properly, nearness (used only as a preposition or an adverb), near; hence, generally, with, by, at, among, etc.
to advise; reflexively, to deliberate or resolve

11.brief: emptiness or vanity; figuratively, something transitory and unsatisfactory; often used as an adverb
properly, to pare off, i.e. lessen; intransitively, to be (or causatively, to make) small or few (or figuratively, ineffective)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),

12.brief: to draw, used in a great variety of applications (including to sow, to sound, to prolong, to develop, to march, to remove, to delay, to be tall, etc.)
properly, to be rubbed or worn; hence (figuratively) to be weak, sick, afflicted; or (causatively) to grieve, make sick; also to stroke (in flattering), entreat
the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything
a tree (from its firmness); hence, wood (plural sticks)
alive; hence, raw (flesh); fresh (plant, water, year), strong; also (as noun, especially in the feminine singular and masculine plural) life (or living thing), whether literally or figuratively
a longing; by implication, a delight (subjectively, satisfaction, objectively, a charm)
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)

13.brief: a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause
to wind tightly (as a rope), i.e. to bind; specifically, by a pledge; figuratively, to pervert, destroy; also to writhe in pain (especially of parturition)
a command, whether human or divine (collectively, the Law)

he (she or it); only expressed when emphatic or without a verb; also (intensively) self, or (especially with the article) the same; sometimes (as demonstrative) this or that; occasionally (instead of copula) as or are
to be safe (in mind, body or estate); figuratively, to be (causatively, make) completed; by implication, to be friendly; by extension, to reciprocate (in various applications)

14.brief: a precept or statute, especially the Decalogue or Pentateuch
properly, something dug, i.e. a (general) source (of water, even when naturally flowing; also of tears, blood (by euphemism, of the female pudenda); figuratively, of happiness, wisdom, progeny)
alive; hence, raw (flesh); fresh (plant, water, year), strong; also (as noun, especially in the feminine singular and masculine plural) life (or living thing), whether literally or figuratively
a noose (for catching animals) (literally or figuratively); by implication, a hook (for the nose)
death (natural or violent); concretely, the dead, their place or state (hades); figuratively, pestilence, ruin

15.brief: good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
graciousness, i.e. subjective (kindness, favor) or objective (beauty)
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
to cover (with a garment); figuratively, to act covertly; by implication, to pillage
permanence; hence (concrete) permanent; specifically a chieftain

16.brief: properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
properly, fat, i.e. (figuratively) stupid or silly

17.brief: a messenger; specifically, of God, i.e. an angel (also a prophet, priest or teacher)
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
to fall, in a great variety of applications (intransitive or causative, literal or figurative)
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
a hinge (as pressed in turning); also a throe (as a phys. or mental pressure); also a herald or erranddoer (as constrained by the principal)
properly, curative, i.e. literally (concretely) a medicine, or (abstractly) a cure; figuratively (concretely) deliverance, or (abstractly) placidity

18.brief: to loosen; by implication, to expose, dismiss; figuratively, absolve, begin
properly, chastisement; figuratively, reproof, warning or instruction; also restraint
properly, to hedge about (as with thorns), i.e. guard; generally, to protect, attend to, etc.
chastisement; figuratively (by words) correction, refutation, proof (even in defence)
to be heavy, i.e. in a bad sense (burdensome, severe, dull) or in a good sense (numerous, rich, honorable; causatively, to make weighty (in the same two senses)

19.brief: a longing; by implication, a delight (subjectively, satisfaction, objectively, a charm)
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
properly, something disgusting (morally), i.e. (as noun) an abhorrence; especially idolatry or (concretely) an idol
properly, fat, i.e. (figuratively) stupid or silly
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)

20.brief: to walk (in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively)
properly, nearness (used only as a preposition or an adverb), near; hence, generally, with, by, at, among, etc.
to be wise (in mind, word or act)
to tend a flock; i.e. pasture it; intransitively, to graze (literally or figuratively); generally to rule; by extension, to associate with (as a friend)
properly, fat, i.e. (figuratively) stupid or silly
properly, to spoil (literally, by breaking to pieces); figuratively, to make (or be) good fornothing, i.e. bad (physically, socially or morally)

21.brief: a criminal, or one accounted guilty
to run after (usually with hostile intent; figuratively (of time) gone by)
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
to be safe (in mind, body or estate); figuratively, to be (causatively, make) completed; by implication, to be friendly; by extension, to reciprocate (in various applications)

good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)

22.brief: good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)
to inherit (as a (figurative) mode of descent), or (generally) to occupy; causatively, to bequeath, or (generally) distribute, instate
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
to hide (by covering over); by implication, to hoard or reserve; figuratively to deny; specifically (favorably) to protect, (unfavorably) to lurk
probably a force, whether of men, means or other resources; an army, wealth, virtue, valor, strength
properly, to miss; hence (figuratively and generally) to sin; by inference, to forfeit, lack, expiate, repent, (causatively) lead astray, condemn

23.brief: properly, plowing, i.e. (concretely) freshly plowed land
there is or are (or any other form of the verb to be, as may suit the connection)
properly, to scrape (literally, to shave; but usually figuratively) together (i.e. to accumulate or increase) or away (i.e. to scatter, remove, or ruin; intransitively, to perish)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles

properly, a verdict (favorable or unfavorable) pronounced judicially, especially a sentence or formal decree (human or (participant's) divine law, individual or collective), including the act, the place, the suit, the crime, and the penalty; abstractly, justice, including a participant's right or privilege (statutory or customary), or even a style

24.brief: to restrain or (reflex.) refrain; by implication, to refuse, spare, preserve; to observe
a scion, i.e. (literally) a stick (for punishing, writing, fighting, ruling, walking, etc.) or (figuratively) a clan
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
to have affection for (sexually or otherwise)
properly, to dawn, i.e. (figuratively) be (up) early at any task (with the implication of earnestness); by extension, to search for (with painstaking)
properly, chastisement; figuratively, reproof, warning or instruction; also restraint

25.brief: properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
the belly, especially the womb; also the bosom or body of anything
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
to lack; by implication, to fail, want, lessen
